May 1919.SECRET.140WAR CABINET 568.Minutes of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10,. Downing Street, S.W.,on Thursday, May 15, 1919, at 12.30 p.m.Present:The Right Hon. A. Bonar Law, M.P. (in the Chair).The Right Hon. the Earl Curzon of I The Bight Hon. A. Chamberlain, M.P.Kedleston, K.G., G.C.S.I., G.C.I.E. 1The following was also present :The Right Hon. Sir A. C. Geddes, K.C.B., M.P., Minister of Reconstruction and national Service.Mr. Thomas Jones, Acting Secretary.Mr. G. M. Evans, Assistant Secretary.Captain L. F. Btjkgis, Assistant Secretary.Egypt. 1. In view of the debate on the Foreign Office Vote in theHouse of Commons that afternoon, the War Cabinet had a short discussion on the position of affairs in Egypt.Teace Celebrations. 2. With reference to War Cabinet 559, Minute 6, lord curzon informed the Cabinet of the arrangements it was proposedto make with regard to Peace Celebrations. He said that his committee had come to the conclusion that the arrangements should be made with as little dislocation as possible to the indus-trial life of the country, and, with this object in view, the hrstweek in August had been proposed, as it would include Saturday,Sunday, and August Bank Holiday; as the Peace Celebrationswere to last only four days, Tuesday would be the only day whichwould disturb business. The Committee had also decided to fix the celebrations for so far ahead as August in case anythinguntoward should happen, which was not outside the bounds of possibility, considering the disturbed state of Europe and theworld at the present moment. Lord Curzon then informed theCabinet in: detail of the form the suggested celebrations shouldtake. He had seen Lord Stamfordham that morning, who would submit the Committee's proposals in detail to His Majesty that afternoon.Mr. Bonar Law said that he thought it was desirable for thepresent to make no announcement with regard to the dates onwhich it was proposed to hold the celebrations.The War Cabinet requested Lord Curzon to circulate the proposals of the Peace Celebra-tions Committee for the information of the Cabinet, andto communicate the proposals to the Prime Minister.[826]-633B 2Office Accommoda- 3. With reference to War Cabinet 550, Minute 2, the Wartion and Demobili- Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by Sir Auckland Geddessation. regarding the staffs of Government departments (G.T.-724.6).Sir Auckland Geddes said that he proposed, in order to reducethe staffs of departments as rapidly as possible, that, as therewas such a large number of men and women engaged on liquidation-tion work for the various departments, all liquidation work shouldbe removed from individual departments and concentrated in asingle building in the outskirts of London, under the control ofan expert or experts appointed with full powers to close and com-plete all outstanding transactions as soon as possible on the most advantageous terms. He thought a maximum establishment of,say, 10,000 should fee allowed, on which progressive reduction could be expected as the work proceeded.Lord Curzon suggested, if it were assumed that ai a givenperiod all offices should revert to normality, and if that periodwere fixed at, say, six months from now, then it might be possibleto lay down a progressive rate of demobilisation of staffs to takeplace during that period, thus reducing the total number of thestaff of each department by so many per week or per month.Sir Auckland Geddes said that he had considered this sug-gestion, and proposed to use it in some degree in connection withhis scheme of liquidation.The War Cabinet decided .To adjourn the discussion until the following Monday, whenMinisters interested in the question should be asked toattend.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,May 15, 1919.o
